author: alexandair
body:
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
Get-Command *wmi*
#or
Get-Command *controlpanel*
```
## Expected behavior

Output should not show removed cmdlets.
## Actual behavior

Output shows removed cmdlets.
## Environment data

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.8
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
WSManStackVersion              3.0
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
PSEdition                      Core
CLRVersion
```

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: @alexandair can you please post which operating system you're on?

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: I can't reproduce this on Ubuntu 14.04 with v6.0.0-alpha.9.

comments.author: ealexjordan
comments.body:
@alexandair - additionally, can you actually copy and paste the results of actual behavior? Cannot repro on 16.04.

ex) 
PS /home/alexj/PowerShell> Get-Command _wmi_
PS /home/alexj/PowerShell> Get-Command _controlpanel_
PS /home/alexj/PowerShell>

comments.author: alexandair
comments.body:
I've experienced that on Windows 10 with PowerShell 6.0.0.8.
It looks like it's fixed  in 6.0.0.9, because I cannot repro it anymore. 

#close

title: Get-Command used with wildcards returns nonexistent cmdlets
